body: Closing as-per INFRA-11185
closing as-per INFRA-11185
closing as-per INFRA-11185
Should we also be validating consistency between `listeners` and `advertised.listeners` security protocols?
@ijuma Good point, we should probably make sure advertised.listeners is a subset of listeners protocols.
Thanks for these improvements, it's really helpful for users to have informative fail-fast behaviour if things are misconfigured.

Thanks @granthenke for your reply.

Yeah I think setting a timeout value in the `AdminRequestPurgatory` and expire it by returning an error code indicating "it has timed out, so the request may either succeed later / eventually, or it has failed and in the worst case leave the cluster in a bad state" is sufficient for ops people to jump in.
@ijuma Updated the PR. Thanks for the review.
@ewencp Mind taking a look?
One minor comment, the rest looks good to me.
@ijuma My bad. Fixed now.
@kunickiaj The example looks reasonable (indeed it seems to be the same one from my blog). It might also be worth adding a comment on the commit methods themselves.

Thanks a lot for the review @junrao .I updated the patch to address your comments.
Some explanation on the changes:
1. The broker now return InvalidMessageException when producer does not set the timestamp type to CreateTime. Previously it just overrides it.
2. It seems difficult to completely avoid unnecessary message magic value check when send fetch response back. I chose the way which I think has the least impact. But it might still break if people roll back message.format.version.
3. I haven't add the configuration sanity check for message.format.version yet. I will do that after we decide on whether it should be a topic level configuration and whether we want to use magic value or ApiVersions.

Happy add the following to the commitSync(Map) method:

> To avoid re-processing the last message read if a consumer is restarted, the committed offset should be the next message your application should consume, i.e. lastProcessedMessageOffset + 1.

If you think other methods should have a note, which, and what information should be added?
Yeah, that works. Probably the same comment should be added to commitAsync(Map,OffsetCommitCallback).
ping @ymatsuda @ewencp for reviews.
Reopen this PR to trigger anther run of Jenkins. Tests failure is unrelated to this change
LGTM
LGTM, thanks @ijuma for the quick turnaround!
All tests pass locally.
@junrao what do you think of this?
@becketqin : Thanks for the patch. Do you plan add some integration tests to cover backward compatibility? We can do that in a separate jira.
@ijuma @becketqin Thoughts on this solution?

@hachikuji Not sure I understand the issue. What library compiled against an older version of the API wouldn't work? As long as `connect-api` and `connect-runtime` versions match when executed, it seems like the current patch would work fine since all of `open`, `close`, `onPartitionsRevoked` and `onPartitionsAssigned` are defined in `connect-api` via `SinkTask`. Any implementations that override `onPartitionsRevoked`/`onPartitionsAssigned` would work indirectly via `open`/`close`.

@ewencp Hmm.. yeah, that sounds right. But I did hit a NoSuchMethodError when I tried to use the hdfs connector compiled against 0.9.0. Now I wonder if it was because the wrong version of the API got loaded into the classpath first.

@hachikuji Was the `NoSuchMethodError` for `open`/`close` or `onPartitionsRevoked`/`onPartitionsAssigned`. The former could make sense if you had old `connect-api` + connector with new `connect-runtime` which tried to invoke `open`/`close`. The latter doesn't seem to make sense with either combination of old/new jars as far as I know.
Updated.
Yeah late to this party but defaulting to anything > 1 is definitely confusing and bad, this is the right fix. Not sure why it was that way, if I did it I plead insanity. :-)

@junrao @ewencp @gwenshap @guozhangwang 
Would any of you have a chance to review this today?
Also, could you update the doc on upgrade?

@ewencp It was for open(). Looks like what happened is the old connect-api jar got on the classpath first since it was included in the development jars for connect-hdfs and connect-jdbc (maybe connect-api should be a provided dependency?). Anyway, looks like a non-issue.
LGTM
I left a few comments. Otherwise, LGTM.
Left a minor comment, but overall LGTM.
@becketqin Added a test for InvalidMessageException

@hachikuji Ok, that sounds like we might have a bug in the packaging scripts in connect-hdfs and connect-jdbc then, although the development and packaged versions differ. Probably worth reviewing.

Based on this update and that we confirmed system tests are passing, LGTM.
LGTM

@gwenshap @ijuma thanks for the comments. I was not sure if it is OK to change current behavior of `CommanLineUtils.parseKeyValueArgs`. It does not seem to be added by mistake, there is a test that checks if it is able to parse key-value pairs with just key. However, I looked for places where it might be passed an argument with no value, and I could not find any such usage. I am now changing `CommanLineUtils.parseKeyValueArgs` behavior. Will update PR after running all tests locally.

It sounds to me that with this change the behavior is going to be the same whether topic deletion is enabled or not. With topic deletion disabled, I created and deleted a topic, and even without broker restart the topic won't show in --list or --describe commands (as if topic deletion is enabled). Is this the intended behavior? or I missed something?
@jjkoshy Thanks for the comments. I moved the sendCompressedMessage to PlaintextConsumerTest to avoid polluting BaseConsumerTest. It looks we only need sending compressed message there.
LGTM.
@granthenke Thanks for the review, updated the patch. I don't feel strong on the method variances as they look pretty much like private calls, just like the package name implies.
Good catch, LGTM. We should double commit this to the 0.9.0 branch. @gwenshap, can you please review?

@ymatsuda Our internal topics are marked as
1. [JobId]-[StateName]-"changelog"
2. [JobId]-[StateName]-"repartition"

while for source KTable, we do not need an internal topic for it.

But when we restore the state, we have a bug where we try to restore the source KTable from [JobId]-[StateName]-"changelog" as well, where we should just restore from topic "StateName".
LGTM
Test failure is irrelevant.
^^ Seems like Jenkins had a transient issue is there a way to re-trigger without doing a force push of the same commit?

@granthenke Thanks for adding the test. LGTM.

I went over all the Exception that might be thrown to user again. I found that UnknowCodecException and UnknownMagicByteException can be returned to clients but does not even have an error mapping. I think we should add them to error mapping. But we probably should create separate jira ticket for that.
@Parth-Brahmbhatt  can you review this.
@guozhangwang Rebased.
Merged to trunk.
@kunickiaj You can close and open the jira again to re-test. However if all tests pass locally, commenting that is often enough.
@ewencp @gwenshap Would you be able to review?
@becketqin Thanks for creating [KAFKA-3203](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3203). I will look into adding those exceptions.
LGTM
@granders I think since the target wasn't trunk you'll need to close this out manually, but I've committed to 0.9.0.
LGTM and thank you for catching this. Will double commit.
A couple of minor comments, looks fine otherwise.

I am not really sure if we should restrict SimpleACLAuthorizer to only supporting UserType. Any reason it wont be able to support any other custom type that user has added if they decide to add a custom authentication layer?
@harshach @fpj can one of you do a final review and merge this if everything looks ok?

@ymatsuda The current StateChangeLogger use the store name directly as the changelog topic name, which is wrong.

The approach is to add a "jobId()" API in the context along with the "taskId()" function, which can then be used by StateChangeLogger to construct the right topic name.
LGTM, and merged to trunk.

@Parth-Brahmbhatt the PR is not restricting SimpleAclAuthorizer to support only UserType, rather we are just exposing to authorizer what principal types authorizer's implementation supports. SimplaAclAuthorizer happens to only support "User" type as of now. A custom implementation can choose to support what ever types it has to. Exposing supported principal types at authorizer level, enables AclCommands or similar tools to check for user errors while specifying principal types.
@SinghAsDev I am not sure why SimpleAclAuthorizer would only support User type currently. Wouldn't it work with any other type as well even in its current state?
@Parth-Brahmbhatt sure it will, however there is no way a user adding acls will ever know that principal types he/she is adding is even correct. For instance, KAFKA-3097.

I guess that's the trade off between stronger schema requirement for validation vs flexibility of supporting any open type. Originally the principal types were case insensitive and we changed it to case sensitive for consistency as topics in kafka are case sensitive. My preference would still be to support flexibility over schema validation. We can add better help messages in ACLCommand to avoid errors like KAFKA-3097. 

If we still chose to go with this PR, I recommend to at least make the supported type a configurable property so a 3rd party authentication scheme does not have to extend SimpleAclAuthorizer just to override the one method.
@ijuma Addressed your reviews. Thank you.

Allowing pluggable authorization is the way to support flexibility, right.
Supported principal types is really something that varies with authorizer
implementation. I do not see why we need one more configuration, when third
party can just provide the info via authorizer interface. Makes sense?

@ijuma Fixed.
LGTM. This addresses an issue with slow start, but also revealed an issue when stop() is called too fast before the other thread has started. We'll file a follow up for that issue.

@ewencp @gwenshap 

Testing: 
Branch builder shows normal: http://confluent-kafka-branch-builder-system-test-results.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/2016-02-04--001.1454568083--confluentinc--remove-vagrantfile-hack--8799afe/report.html

In this environment, we have
Vagrant 1.7.2
vagrant-aws (0.7.0)
vagrant-hostmanager (1.7.0)
vagrant-share (1.1.5, system)

I have also manually verified typical lifecycle commands `vagrant up --provider=aws ...`, `vagrant halt`, `vagrant destroy` on OSX, and on an ec2 instance running Ubuntu, both with vagrant-hostmanager 1.5.0, and with vagrant-hostmanager 1.7.1
For reference, additional follow up [here](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3211)

Lets take the scenario of someone wanting custom authentication but default authorization(SimpleAclAuthorizer):

Current scenario:
- No extra work needed but no help message displayed to the user about newly added types.

After this patch:
- Extend SimpleAclAuthorizer.
- Override a single method getSupportedPrincipalTypes to list the custom principalType that their custom authentication added.
- General packaging of this new custom authorizer with all the other classes and configuration changes to make this new class the authorizer.

If we add config for supported Types:
- Only the config for supported type has to change.

Let me know if I am wrong in the above evaluation. In addition, if we decide that we want to add stronger validations as recommended in this PR, I would recommend that we add actual validation in SimpleAclAuthorizer. In the current PR someone trying to add the ACLs using CLI will get an error and someone adding Acls programmatically won't.
LGTM
LGTM, good to be rid of that code and the restriction on the version of `vagrant-hostmanager`.
LGTM
LGTM and merged to trunk.
Not sure about this one. It's nice that we are trying to do the right thing automatically, but is it intuitive? Particularly for the case where there are multiple listeners.

@Parth-Brahmbhatt please find my response inline.

> Current scenario:
> No extra work needed but no help message displayed to the user about newly added types.
> After this patch:

This is what we want to fix. This will help us avoid bunch of user group/ JIRA questions/complains on why Kafka authorization is not working for them.

> Extend SimpleAclAuthorizer.
> Override a single method getSupportedPrincipalTypes to list the custom principalType that their custom authentication added.
> General packaging of this new custom authorizer with all the other classes and configuration changes to make this new class the authorizer.

This is how the community agreed on supporting pluggable authorization, build custom authorizer implementation and package it. This PR does not change current behavior of `SimpleAclAuthorizer`. This is how third party authorization implementations would work even now, right?

> If we add config for supported Types:
> Only the config for supported type has to change.

Yet another config. We should try to avoid any new configs, however if multiple people are in favor of this we can go ahead with this. @gwenshap @ijuma what do you guys think?

> I would recommend that we add actual validation in SimpleAclAuthorizer. In the current PR someone trying to add the ACLs using CLI will get an error and someone adding Acls programmatically won't.

The reason this PR has the checks in CLI is to fail fast. I see your point on programatic access of `SimpleAclAuthorizer`. However, we need to define the expectation of Authorizer interface. We can either say that Authorizer interface, `addAcls` and `removeAcls`, will fail for improper Acls or we can say it does not check. When we are exposing `getSupportedPrincipalTypes`, it is only fair to assume that onus is on clients/callers to check if they are passing proper ACLs in create/remove acls commands.
@gwenshap @ijuma mind giving it another pass?

@miguno @ymatsuda 

This also updates the examples following the current serde system to make them runnable. And some TODO markers for possible improvements once serde is completed.

@ijuma The thought here is to have a good/safe default configuration based on the "required" parameters. If a user configures SASL, SSL or both and does not change security.inter.broker.protocol from the default. Either they are insecure or their broker won't start. KAFKA-3194 made it a bit safer and the messaging more clear. But I would prefer to prevent the issue in the first place. 

I guess a good question is how often do users run with multiple listeners configured?
LGTM, double committing to 0.9.0 and trunk.

> If a user configures SASL, SSL or both and does not change security.inter.broker.protocol from the default. Either they are insecure or their broker won't start.

It's just the latter right? The former would only happen if a PLAINTEXT port was also configured, which implies that the broker is accepting unsecured connections. Also, the PLAINTEXT port may even be selected if it's the first advertised.listener.

> I guess a good question is how often do users run with multiple listeners configured?

Yes. And whether forcing the users to make the decision explicitly (a failed broker start with a good error message) or if we can choose a good enough default so that things just work.
@ijuma Thanks for your comments! I addressed them, if you want to take a look one more time.
Merged to trunk.

@ijuma Right. We need to decide which approach to take. Setting a valid (perhaps not optimal) protocol as a default or failing and forcing the user to choose.

Part of my motivation is to minimize the parameters that need to be set/managed in normal deployments.
+1 - thanks Becket
@jjkoshy, we probably want to double-commit this to 0.9.0 as well.
true - will cherry-pick that
